0.title: the warmest three/two
paragraphs: The Warmest 3/2mm of the season was the Rip Curl Heat Seeker. Wetsuits competing for the title were:

1.title: the comfort stretch award four/three
paragraphs: The wetsuit for those who like their yoga in silk pants is the O’Neill Hyperfreak Comp. The Wetsuits entered into the Stretchiest and Comfiest 4/3mm category were:

3.title: the budget warrior (suits under $315)
paragraphs: The finest wetsuit for the frugal is the O’Neill Hyperfreak Comp

4.title: the fastest drying
paragraphs: All suits entered the fastest drying category, but after one use of the Rip Curl Heat Seeker featuring their Flashbomb lining, it was clear, no suit dries as fast as a Rip Curl.

5.title: feeling lovely (most stylish)
paragraphs: Like the fastest drying, every suit was entered into the best looking category. After careful analysis, the FERAL 4/3mm backzip was unanimously voted the sexiest wetsuit on the market.
Just like the 90’s, backzips are back!

0.title: Billabong
paragraphs: For such an established wetsuit brand, Billabong has been taking huge marketing swings in the past year, releasing both a build-your-own wetsuit feature on their site and infusing their 2019 line with a Nobel Prize-winning super-fiber: graphene. We'd read the brochure and seen the promotional material, but the question remained: was this graphene stuff actually any good? Armed with Billabong's Furnace Ultra 3/2 and Furnace Carbon 4/3, we took to the frigid waters of Santa Cruz and sampled this Nobel- Prize-winning fiber's warmth and comfort capacities.

1.title: Feral
paragraphs: The only perceivable advantage Feral had against its mainstream competitors was their actual wetsuit material. Yamamoto rubber, hailing from Japan, is widely regarded as the premier neoprene on the market. It's more densely packed than other types of rubber, which means there's less room for water to slip between the cracks and be absorbed by the suit. This results in a theoretically lighter and drier body bag. Those quantitative benefits are great on paper, but the Yamamoto's single greatest perk was its gentle, caressing feel against the skin. Seriously, it's like silk pajamas. Once you slide in, ya never wanna get out.

2.title: O'Neill
paragraphs: As founded by the inventor of wetsuits himself, Mr. Jack O’Neill, this Santa Cruz brand is surfing’s first and most iconic neoprene manufacturer. Legacy aside, we wanted to know if O'Neill, a company founded in 1952, could really make the most high-tech wetsuits in 2019. The answer came swiftly and without a need to deliberate. From the second we slipped into O'Neill's historic neoprene, it became apparent that their wetsuits were absurdly stretchy and comfortable—more so than any other brand in our test, and it wasn't even close.

3.title: Quiksilver
paragraphs: In the Slater days, the Quiksilver brand reached incredible heights, the ultimate expression of their wealth being The Crossing—a 75-foot charter boat wrapped in company colors and sent around the globe for all the world to see. Since those times, the company has gone through a litany of changes but is in the midst of a vibrant upswing. Now the question is, does the biggest surf brand of the new millennium still remember how to make a decent wetsuit?

4.title: Rip Curl
paragraphs: In last year's wetsuit test, Rip Curl's Flashbomb Heat Seeker earned awards as both the warmest and fastest-drying suit. We wanted to know if the recently acquired brand could retain those same quality metrics in 2019. Hint: they did. Whether it's those Tron patches on the arms or the insular lining that was ripped straight out of drywall (note: our wetsuit tester has exhibited no signs of mesothelioma), that damn Flashbomb Heat Seeker is warmer than summer asphalt.

5.title: Volte
paragraphs: Volte is the 2010 Toyota Tacoma of wetsuits. Functional, fairly priced, and designed for someone who surfs daily. Based out of Oceanside, California, we wanted to see if this developing brand could compete with the big swinging dicks of the wetsuit industry. Volte did that and then some, even sneaking their 4/5 hooded into the top-3 most comfortable suits—against a crop of non-hooded 4/3s!
